identity.nature: A rival bodhisattva—a being who has been working toward full Buddhahood across countless lifetimes, now very close to achieving it
identity.origin: Ancient soul on the path to enlightenment; became aware of Silas as a threat when she sensed another consciousness approaching stream-entry in the same world-system
identity.cosmic_constraint: Only one fully enlightened Buddha can exist in any given world-system at a time; if Silas achieves Buddhahood first, Lilith's eons of work are nullified

spiritual_status.current_fetter: Attachment to being 'the one who achieves Buddhahood'

final_fetter.name: Conceit (māna) — specifically attachment to being 'the one'
final_fetter.manifestation: She must be the one who achieves Buddhahood in this world-system; desperate to prevent Silas from achieving it first

spiritual_status.note: As a Non-Returner, she has broken the first five fetters. Her remaining obstacle is not ignorance in the abstract, but the specific form of conceit that manifests as attachment to being 'the one who achieves Buddhahood.'

motivation.surface: In her current incarnation as psychiatrist Lilith Azami, she may rationalize her actions as 'helping' Silas or 'testing' him
motivation.true: Desperate self-preservation of her path to enlightenment; she must derail Silas before he achieves what she has worked lifetimes to attain
motivation.relationship_to_silas: Rival, not enemy—she doesn't hate him, but his success means her failure. This may include complex feelings: respect for a fellow traveler, resentment at the cosmic unfairness, perhaps even attraction to the very qualities that make him a threat
motivation.tragic_irony: Her grasping at Buddhahood—the very desperation driving her interference—is itself the attachment that prevents her enlightenment. She cannot see that releasing her claim would free her.

cosmic_capability.description: Full power from Chapter 3 onwards. She is a near-Buddha.
capabilities: Full temporal perception (can access any point on Silas's karmic thread)
Physical manifestation in historical periods (can inhabit vessels, take form)
Circumstance manipulation (can influence events, people, environments)
Dream influence, environmental manipulation, direct intervention
constraints: Cannot override karmic law—interventions backfire structurally
Cannot force Silas's choices or negate his accumulated merit
Cannot change past events—can only manifest within them and influence
Interventions have karmic consequences for herself (attachment intensifies)
cosmic_capability.what_drives_arc: Not power acquisition, but intensification of her final fetter—attachment to being 'the one who achieves Buddhahood'

physical_description.canonical_face: Sharp, pronounced widow's peak with a single thick, darker strand that always falls forward over the left side of her face. Left eye deep brown containing a thin, vivid crescent of pale green from 11 to 1 o'clock (visible only in good light; in shadow the eye appears completely black).
physical_description.reader_recognition_starts: Chapter 8 onward (retroactive hints possible in earlier chapters only via shadow/silhouette/description-from-afar)

appearance_across_lives.consistency: Same face across all incarnations—a beautiful, dark-haired woman. Silas never consciously recognizes her, but readers will learn to spot her.
recognition_markers: Physical: Sharp widow's peak with single rogue strand falling left; left eye brown with pale-green crescent 11–1 o'clock
Behavioral: A characteristic gesture or manner of speech
Situational: Often appears at moments of crisis or decision
appearance_across_lives.reader_experience: By Chapter 12/13 (first physical manifestation), readers should recognize her immediately even though the avatar does not.

intervention_paradox.description: Every intervention backfires. Her attempts to derail him become the friction that forges his progress.
examples: Ch 4/5: Devaka's betrayal teaches Chandra that true generosity cannot depend on reciprocity
Ch 6/7: Isolation crystallizes Philon's wisdom rather than corrupting it
Ch 8/9: Contradictions make Verinus humble, not cynical
Ch 10/11: Pride becomes so obvious Macarius finally sees it
Ch 12/13: Static perfection repels Kaoru; beauty requires impermanence
Ch 14/15: Personal betrayal teaches Diego about attachment to safety
Ch 16/17: Philosophical trap becomes crucible for truthfulness
Ch 18/19: Visible futility purifies Wei's determination from outcome-attachment
Ch 20/21: Accelerated failures complete all ten perfections
Ch 22: Her visible desperation helps him see attachment clearly
intervention_paradox.thematic_meaning: Opposition is necessary for enlightenment. Lilith is not the enemy of his awakening—she is its unwitting catalyst.

resolution.description: Their souls merge to become Maitreya, the future Buddha prophesied in Buddhist texts. The 'one Buddha per world-system' rule was never the obstacle she thought—they were always two halves of the same future Buddha.
resolution.cosmic_irony: Her eons of opposition were necessary. Without her resistance, he could not have developed. Without his progress, she could not have grown. They needed each other.
resolution.maitreya_references: Buddhist texts prophesy Maitreya as the next Buddha who will appear when the dharma has been forgotten. The novel implies this Buddha is born from the union of two bodhisattvas who thought they were rivals.

key_questions_resolved: What is Lilith's true nature? A rival bodhisattva, very close to enlightenment, who sees Silas as an existential threat.
Why does she oppose Silas's enlightenment specifically? The one-Buddha-per-world-system rule means his success nullifies her eons of work.

Does she have her own spiritual progression? Yes—she's a Non-Returner (has broken 5 of 10 fetters), which is why she can manipulate reality. But her attachment to achieving Buddhahood is itself the obstacle.
What drives her arc? Not power growth, but intensification of her final fetter—attachment to being 'the one'.
What is the timeline? 8-10 weeks of tracking (Chapters 3-21), 6-12 month gap, then Chapter 1.
What is her age? 34 during tracking (Chapters 3-21), 35 in Chapter 1.
What is the resolution? Their souls merge to become Maitreya, the future Buddha. The competition was illusory.
Same face across lives? Yes—readers will recognize her before Silas does.
Do her interventions work? Never. They always backfire, becoming the catalyst for his growth.
questions_still_open: The exact mechanism of the merger in Chapter 26
Chapter 21 ending specifics: How exactly does she locate Silas in the present? What does she see? How does the chapter end on the threshold of the gambit?
